title: Week 02: Explore Eris Codebase and existing IS related tools
text:
Weekly project meeting

Reviewed project aims and scope
Bunya Training on the last Friday of each month
Assessment on checkpoint meeting and project plan (draft report sent it on 18 Aug)
Proposed the testing dataset

Publish the logbook





UQCCR Building induction





Started reviewing eris code base

Data structure

Custom python classes (e.g Record, SeqFile, Qualifier, Feature, Edge, Seq, etc) are used to represent biological entities and annotation.
These calsses store metadata, sequences, and other attributes

External Program and database handling

Wrap calls to external tools (minimap2, pyrodigal). Also handle csv and fna ISfinder data as the Eris data structure
Function to construct command line argument, run program, and manipulate their outputs

File input/ouput

Read and parse common bioinformatics format (fasta, gfa, etc)
Parse it into Eris data structure
Output the scan eris data structure to the file

Pipeline

Worklow logic to scan pipeline in scan.py from handle the input data, processes it to Eris data structure, run external tools (minimap, orf finder), travesing the feature, and predict the insertion effect

CLI handling

Manage user inputs and pipeline execution via CLI commands.

Feature vs. Element in ERIS — Discussion with Tom

Feature:

A label for any part of sequences
Includes IS element (mobile_element), CDS, repeat region?, and other annotations
Tracks under the genome sequence on the genome viewer

Element:

Specially referes to insertion sequences detected by the mapping process

Feature graph

Nodes represent biological features
Edges represent overlap or flanking relationship between features
Promoter inside IS element are handled separately and not included in the graph

Traverdsal and logic

Breadth first search (BFS) is used to find CDS and feature overlapping or flanking IS elements

Data structure:

Eris does not use de Brujin graphs for representing overlaps








Downloaded the Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)
Perfomed genome assembly from the raw paired end reads:

spades.py -1 $PWD/data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz -2 $PWD/data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz -o $PWD/outputs

Run Eris using API interface:


from eris.scan import Scanner
from pathlib import Path

p = Path('/Users/adimascf/UQ-resources/SEM2/research-project/project-scratch/outputs/genomes/')
with Scanner() as scanner:
    results = list(scanner.scan(*p.iterdir()))


for result in results:
    for feature in result.features[:10]:
        print(feature)

upregulated_is = []
for result in results:
    for k, v in result.contexts.items():
        if v.effect == "upregulated":
            upregulated_is.append(v.id)


# get only upregulated effect scenario indeces
upregulated_context = []
for result in results:
    for feature, kv in zip(result.features, result.contexts.items()):
        if kv[1].id in upregulated_is:
            upregulated_context.append([feature.id, feature.qualifiers, kv[1]])
print(upregulated_context)

# get only the IS name, and counter
from collections import defaultdict
is_found = defaultdict(int)
for result in results:
    for feature in result.features:
        if feature.kind == "mobile_element":
            is_name  = str(feature.qualifiers[0]).replace("name:Z:", "")
            is_found[is_name] += 1
print(f"{len(is_found)} IS are found")

51 IS are found



from eris.io import SeqFile
from pathlib import Path
import os

# extract IS sequence from ISfinder that are found the sample and and write into fasta file
filename = "is_found.fasta"
if os.path.exists(filename):
    os.remove(filename)

n = 0
isf_path = Path('/Users/adimascf/UQ-resources/SEM2/research-project/eris/src/eris/data/IS.fna')
isf_fasta = SeqFile(isf_path, format_="fasta")
for record in isf_fasta:
    if record.id in is_found:
        with open("is_found.fasta", "a") as file:
            identifier = ">" + record.id + "\n"
            file.write(identifier)
            data = str(record.seq)
            length = len(data)
            nlines = (length + 59) // 60
            for line in range(nlines):
                lineofseq = data[line*60:(line+1)*60] + "\n"
                file.write(lineofseq)
        n += 1
print(n)

51


Started exploring isescan

Using input data from Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)


isescan.py --seqfile genomes/contigs.fasta --output isescan-results --nthread 2

Started exploring ISMapper

Using input data from Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)
Input reference from Klebsiella pneumoniae GCF_000016305.1
Query IS from IS that are found by Eris both partial and full is_found.fasta file


ismap --reads data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz data/SRR20082569_2.fastq.gz --queries ../logbook/weekly-logs/is_found.fasta --reference data/GCF_000016305.1_ASM1630v1_genomic.gbff --output_dir ismapper-results/

title: Week 02: Explore Eris Codebase and existing IS related tools
text:
Weekly project meeting

Reviewed project aims and scope
Bunya Training on the last Friday of each month
Assessment on checkpoint meeting and project plan (draft report sent it on 18 Aug)
Proposed the testing dataset

Publish the logbook





UQCCR Building induction





Started reviewing eris code base

Data structure

Custom python classes (e.g Record, SeqFile, Qualifier, Feature, Edge, Seq, etc) are used to represent biological entities and annotation.
These calsses store metadata, sequences, and other attributes

External Program and database handling

Wrap calls to external tools (minimap2, pyrodigal). Also handle csv and fna ISfinder data as the Eris data structure
Function to construct command line argument, run program, and manipulate their outputs

File input/ouput

Read and parse common bioinformatics format (fasta, gfa, etc)
Parse it into Eris data structure
Output the scan eris data structure to the file

Pipeline

Worklow logic to scan pipeline in scan.py from handle the input data, processes it to Eris data structure, run external tools (minimap, orf finder), travesing the feature, and predict the insertion effect

CLI handling

Manage user inputs and pipeline execution via CLI commands.

Feature vs. Element in ERIS — Discussion with Tom

Feature:

A label for any part of sequences
Includes IS element (mobile_element), CDS, repeat region?, and other annotations
Tracks under the genome sequence on the genome viewer

Element:

Specially referes to insertion sequences detected by the mapping process

Feature graph

Nodes represent biological features
Edges represent overlap or flanking relationship between features
Promoter inside IS element are handled separately and not included in the graph

Traverdsal and logic

Breadth first search (BFS) is used to find CDS and feature overlapping or flanking IS elements

Data structure:

Eris does not use de Brujin graphs for representing overlaps








Downloaded the Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)
Perfomed genome assembly from the raw paired end reads:

spades.py -1 $PWD/data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz -2 $PWD/data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz -o $PWD/outputs

Started exploring Eris CLI and API reference

from collections import defaultdict
is_found = defaultdict(int)
for result in results:
    for feature in result.features:
        if feature.kind == "mobile_element":
            is_name  = str(feature.qualifiers[0]).replace("name:Z:", "")
            is_found[is_name] += 1
print(f"{len(is_found)} IS are found")

51 IS are found



from eris.io import SeqFile
from pathlib import Path
import os

# extract IS sequence from ISfinder that are found the sample and and write into fasta file
filename = "is_found.fasta"
if os.path.exists(filename):
    os.remove(filename)

n = 0
isf_path = Path('/Users/adimascf/UQ-resources/SEM2/research-project/eris/src/eris/data/IS.fna')
isf_fasta = SeqFile(isf_path, format_="fasta")
for record in isf_fasta:
    if record.id in is_found:
        with open("is_found.fasta", "a") as file:
            identifier = ">" + record.id + "\n"
            file.write(identifier)
            data = str(record.seq)
            length = len(data)
            nlines = (length + 59) // 60
            for line in range(nlines):
                lineofseq = data[line*60:(line+1)*60] + "\n"
                file.write(lineofseq)
        n += 1
print(n)

51


Started exploring isescan

Using input data from Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)


isescan.py --seqfile genomes/contigs.fasta --output isescan-results --nthread 2

Started exploring ISMapper

Using input data from Klebsiella pneumoniae WGS data (SRR20082569)
Input reference from Klebsiella pneumoniae GCF_000016305.1
Query IS from IS that are found by Eris both partial and full is_found.fasta file


ismap --reads data/SRR20082569_1.fastq.gz data/SRR20082569_2.fastq.gz --queries ../logbook/weekly-logs/is_found.fasta --reference data/GCF_000016305.1_ASM1630v1_genomic.gbff --output_dir ismapper-results/

title: Week 01: literature review, exploring relevant databases, and evaluating IS detection tools
text:
Setup Bunya HPC account and access, read IS related papers from Leah and Tom, compared the existing tools and publicly available database.






Weekly project meeting

Tom introduced eris, and explained how the tool works.
Leah made google docs to list the things that I need to do
Leah and Tom send IS related papers for me to study

Submitted the Bunya application form.
Need to wait 48 hours to get respond from RCC.
Started reading the following papers:

IS-capades of Klebsiella pneumoniae: Insertion sequences drive metabolic loss in obscure sub-lineages


These four sub lineages SL91 and SL10031 (also referred to as subspecies 19 ozaenae), SL10032 (subspecies rhinoscleromatis) and SL82 have relatively high number of IS, each with differenT profile. These high number of IS are linked to the loss of the ability to use many nutrients for metabolic process.
IS may affect metabolism by directly disrupting nearby genes or indirectly through genome rearrangements over time. Despite these loses, the sub lineages still keep a core of metabolic traits that likely help the survive.


A metagenomics pipeline reveals insertion sequence-driven evolution of the microbiota


Developed new IS database ISOSDB, expanding IS diversity of ISfinder, it is built from single and metagenome data.
Built the pseudoR to wok with the new database, can use metagenomic data for the input.
IS in gut bacteria is diverse regardless of the lifestyle and geopgraphy. These inertions usually target accessory genes (not cor genes for survival?)
iORF evenets is usually unique to individual microbiome
IS insertions are temporary stable and maintained, and others only detected at specific timepoint. Microbiota actively forming new insertions.
Antibiotic pressure cause significant loss of IS diversity, and usually unrecovered afftar the expossure.
Diet intervensions affect the IS insertions, in respond to metabolic process adaptation






Started reading the following papers:

Mobile Genetic Elements Associated with Antimicrobial Resistance


Review specieally highlights ESKAPEE pathogens (E. coli, K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, S. aureus) in the resistance dissemination.
MGE including IS, transposon, integron, gene cassette, plasmid are driver horizontal gene transfer of resistance genes among pathogenes. They play significant role in the acquisition, accumulation, and dissemination of antimicrobial resistence (AMR) genes.
Classification of IS by:

Amino acids transpoase motifs, DDE (Asp-Asp-Glu) is the most common.
Transposition mechanisms, cut or copy paste

Terminal inverted repeats typically found at both end of IS
ISfinder is manually curated database for IS elements.
Naming shceme: it comnbines species origin and an ID number (e.g., ISAba1 from Acinetobacter baumannii).
IS can activate resistance genes by inserting upstream, distruping genes nearby, or facilitating cimposite transposon
IS can flank resistence gene(s) to form composite transposon
IS integrate into plasmid, driving HGT
Multiple identical MGE collapse during WGS assembly, resistance islands become fragmented across contigs






My access request to Bunya HPC has been approved.
Logged into HPC, set up keygen ssh
Started reading the following papers:

Everyman’s Guide to Bacterial Insertion Sequences


IS play big roles in the genomic evolutions, including gene rearrangement, gene modulation, and HGT.
THey have high diversity > 4000 identified IS, it will increase along with sequencing project, and make it the boundaries with other MGE less clear
Family definitions are qualitative/descriptive.
IS is defined a short (0.7 and 2.5 kb) DNA elements encoding only enzymes requires for its mobility. Their genetic compotition are compact with mosly two open reading frames (orfs) which occupy the entire length of the IS and terminate in flanking imperfect terminal repeat sequences (IR).
ISfinder is curated IS database as well as it provides a framework for nomenclature and IS classification into related groups or families.
Major IS groups is characterised by the chemestry they use to breaking and rejoining: motif DDE (and DEDD) and HUH enzymes.
DDE transposases IS are distinguished by the second (“nontransferred”) strand is processed:

Coointegrate (copy and paste): IS6
Cut and paste in, with 2 bp footprint in donor site: IS630
Cut and paste in, with haipin formation: IS4
Replicate circle formed, with donor retained (copy and paste): IS3, IS2, IS911

IS is ismple TE with only transpoase, composite transposon is two IS elements flanking genes, unit tranposon is ingle unit Tpase with cargo, ICE is integrated + conjugative transfer
Transporter IS carry passager genes that are not related to mobility, antibiotic resistance genes (ISCgl1, IS481 family)
IS91/ISCR group is associated with diverse antibiotic resistance genes
IS can rapidly invrease copy number (expansion), remove unnecessary genes (in nuitrient rich environtment).
IS can modulate gene expression (resistance gene) in two main ways:

insert in coding sequence and distrupt the expression
bring the promoter, induce gene activation.

IS insertion is not entirely random:

Some IS prefer specific motifs, IS630 prefer TA in the target
Some IS prefer AT-rich or GC-rich regions

ISfinder groups IS into families based on structural and functional characteristics (Transpoase motifs, IR, TSD, orf, target preference, etc)
29 IS families identified in ISfinder
IS doesn’t include every IS that exists, the sequence come from reseachers who studied and submited it. New database expansion or exploration will likely lead to new families or groups.
IS1 (DDE transpoase) plays a role in spreading antibiotic resistence by flanking that genes on transposon or plasmid.
IS3 (DDE transpoase) is the biggest IS family with >550 members found in > 270 species


ISfinder: the reference centre for bacterial insertion sequences


ISfinder defines ISD as short genetically compact DNA segments (between 0.7 and 2.5 kb) encoding no functions other than those involved in their mobility.
ISfinder is manual curation (need to fill out the submission form) exclusively for IS database. It also play role as Inaming convention/nomenclature).
Follow naming system from restriction enzyme. example: ISKpn1 (found in Klebsiella pneumoniae, and unique identifier 1). Drawback: some IS elements are found in multiple taxa. Hystorical number blocks are preserved in the database.
ISfinder utilises MySQL structure
It provides: DNA sequence, orf/poteintal coding sequence, TIR and TSD, Taxonomic origin, IS family, reference, NCBI taxonomy, also tools like BLAST.






Completed the Health Safety and Wellness Induction training on Blackboard
Complerted the Annual Fire Safety training on Blackboard
Started reading the following papers:

Quantitative assessment of insertion sequence impact on bacterial genome architecture


They introduced ISseeker to anotate IS element in the draft genome assembly
Using genome assembly draft as an input, less computational cost.
It identifies IS by blasting their flanking sequences (500 bp) to a reference genome. Both full long contigs includes IS and flanks and and truncated IS (but flanks remain)
These flank can tell us where the IS location in the host genome.
If match is found, IS is annotated as mapped. The location relative to adjacent genes in the reference genome (user specified) is reported.
It doesn’t use ISfinder
It does not give us the full inserted sequence, it doesn’t classifiy IS, it doesn’t give functional effect
Phylogenetically they suggested that many IS insertion in A. baumannii and K. pneumoniae are conserved.
IS elements can insert intragenically (within genes) or intergenically (between genes)
Multiple IS insertion in same region (A. baumannii)
Although the genome size is about 30 % smaller than K. pneumoniae genomes (~5.6 Mbp), IS element density from A. baumannii is greater.


Impact of insertion sequences on convergent evolution of Shigella species


IS in Shigella genomes account 5-8% of bases, much higher than E.coli with <1%.
They used ISMapper to identify insertion sites in chromosomes.
Within each Shigella species (S. dysenteriae, S. flexneri, S. sonnei), there are variation in both the number and the location of IS insertion. These IS insertion patterns could be use to differentiate phylogenetic lineages.
IS transposition has been ongoing since each species split
S. sonnei, S. dysenteriae, and S. flexneri share 53%, 82%, ~33% sites between lineages, respectively. IS Insertion can reflect recent and previous evolution history.
Five common IS (IS1, IS2, IS4, IS600, IS911) made upp most insertion in Shigella reference genomes, with IS1 contributed the most. These insertion contributing in convergent evolution of the genus.
They measured recent IS activity by counted strain specific insertions divided by strain specific SNVs. S. sonnei shows significantly higher recent activity for all five IS
Proportion of pseudogenes associated with IS insertion is 50% in S. sonnei, 22% in S. flexneri and 35% in S. dysenteriae. Significant number of convserved pseudogenes were interupted by IS.
Insertions events are less frequent in gene regions (0.20 in S. flexneri, 0.29 in S. sonnei, 0.11 in S. dysenteriae), suggesting purifying selection against insertion in CDS.
IS contributed to pathways loss in each species. Disrupting individual metabolic gene or multiple hits within the same pathway. All ancient pathway inactivation events (>80% of genomes) within metabolic reactions were IS insertions in S. sonnei and S. dysenteriae, and 30% in S. flexneri.
ISmapper detects IS by mapping paired reads to a list of query IS sequences. Then it finds pairs that only one mapped to the query (unmapped mates correspond to the flanking genomic DNA). These “flanking” reads then map to the reference genome to get insertion location.


Transposases are the most abundant, most ubiquitous genes in nature


Using genomes and metagenomes data, they found that transposase gene that produce eznyme that enable movement within part of genome outnumber any other type of genes, including housekeeping genes.
Previously labelled as selfish genes with no other purpose than propagating themse;f, the finding that transpoase more abundance that all essential genes, support the idea that these DNA elements play role in host adaptation.
This group of mobile element leads to mutation and genome rearrangements that affect diversiciation and adaptation, and drive evolution.


IS26 and the IS26 family: versatile resistance gene movers and genome reorganizers


IS26 is found in plasmid and chromosome of pathogens like E. coli and Klebsiella.
It is known for good at spreading resistance gene
IS26 is 820 bp long with perfectly matching 14 bp TIR. S26 includes a single open reading frame, tnp26, that encodes the 234-aa DDE transposase designated Tnp26, and Tnp26 is required for movement. Movement of IS26 to a new location generates a TSD of 8 bp.
Its promoters within the TIRs allow not only expression of its own gene but can also enhance antibiotic resistance gene expression nearby.
IS26 forms cointegrates rather than simply inserting a copy itself. The incoming replicon carrying IS26 becomes flanked by two IS26 copies.

IS26 has unquie moving mechanism, that enables them spreading resistence genes. It has two distinct cointegration, Pseudo composite transposon (PCT) formation.

IS26 enables A. baumannii to capture and integrate resistance genes






Compared ISFinder vs ISOSDB

ISFinder is a manually curated IS database, the submission requires the researchers to fill out the form. It also provide naming convention for IS.
ISOSDB include much larger collection of IS sequences than ISFinder (extended version). They author identified IS element using OASIS from publicly available metagenome and genome. OASIS takes genbank format file (.gbk) as an input and alrady transposases annotated. It has different naming convention with ISFinder (ISOSDB prefix) The IS elements are included in the ISOSDB if meet following criteria:

at least two copies of the IS element in a single genome,
flanked by terminal IRs
it has significant nucleotide homology to an IS element in ISFinder or has a putative transposase.


Compared the existing tools

OASIS

OASIS using annotated transposase from genebank file. It then groups IS into multicopy ISs and single-copy ISs. The edges (or flanking?) of Multicopy ISs defined with homology (maximum likelihood). Edges of single and multicopy (re)define by IR. Identifies partial and missing IS using blast. Then group IS sequeces using hierechial clustering.
Classifiy the detected IS sequence using ISfinder database.
It doesn’t require the user to provide a reference genome or to provide query IS sequence. The input only gbk file. It relies on the gene (of Tpases) annotation form the genebank file.

IS_mapper

ISMapper takes as input: a set of paired end Illumina reads, an IS query sequence in fasta format, a referenc genome sequence, in GenBank or FASTA format.
The paired end read then are mapped to the IS query, looking for unmapped mate reads, that is reads representing the sequences directly flanking the IS (is it always the case?). The left and right flanking sequences is then mapped to the referenc egenome to find the location of the query IS. Left and right end blocks are extracted, close indiciating (known IS position relative tto the reference), overlaped (novel IS position).

ISSeeker

ISSeeker takes assembly draft/collection of contigs as an input. The program aligns (using BLAST) collection of IS elemets to the collection of cotigs (assembly draft), looking for full or partial (edges) matches, then it extraxts both flanking regions of that matches (500bp). These flanking (of insetion) region then mapped again to the reference to get the relative position in the genome, infering where the insertion events happened.
It attempts to pair left and right flanks that mapped in the same location in the referecne genome to infer a single insertion event.

ISEScan

The program only use a (draft) genome or metagenome sequence (fasta) as an input. It scan and translate to protein sequence for each enry from the file to identify the transpoase sequences.
It uses profile Hidden Markov Models (pHMMs), that is built from Transposase sequence by evolutionary relationshiop, to search remote homolog of transposase sequences from the given fasta.
Similiar o OASIS, it groups the IS candidate into single copy and multicopy to identify the edges (boundaries). Then reomve redundants result with hierarchical clustering. Boundaries of a single copy IS is defined by IR, multi copy ISs is determined by homology of those sequences and shared IRs.
After idnetifyng transposase ORF, the porgram defines the flanking regions (regions around ORF). It then predicts IRs using local alignment (SW) algorithm to compare left side regions DNA sequences againts the reverse complement of the right side regions. It searches both nearby and farther regions.

pseudoR

IS detection pipeline that uses ISOSDB
It doesn’t rely on paired-end information, instead it uses split reqd approach (looking reads that partially mapped to the assembled genome?).
Sequencing reads are first mapped to the assembled contigs. The program then collects all read that are unmapped. These reads the are aligned again to a ISOSDB search for IS terminal ends. If a read contains an IS terminus, that part is deleted, and the rest of the sequence is remapped to the assembled contigs.

digIS

The program searches for the most conserved part of Tpase (DDE motifs), the catalytic domain.
It takes genome (complete?) in fasta as an input, optionally with annotation file gbk. It then translates whole DNA sequence from the input file into protein sequence. Catalyc domain the input sequence is detected using manually curated pHMMs, and the matche regions are tagged as seeds. The seeds are theen extended to get the transaposase sequence of predicted IS.
pHMMs are built from MSAa of transposase catalyc domain for each IS family using sequences from ISFinder.








Lineage: A broad group of bacteria that shares a common evolutionary ancestor.
Sublineage: A small group within a lineage that diverge further, because accumulation of mutation, IS insertions, and other genome rearrangements.
Inverted repeats (IRs): short DNA sequences at both end of a IS, where the sequence on one end is the reverse complement of the other end (boundaries of the IS). Inverted and complementary.
Direct Target Repeats (DTRs): Created during integration, identical sequences (footprint of insertion)
iORF: Insertion event of IS in the ORF (genes) that may knock off or regulate the gene expression.
Composite Transposon: Two IS in the flanking segement with (resistence) gene in the middle.
Target Site Duplications (TSD): short flanking direct repeats (DR, typically ∼3 to 14 bp
Gene cassette: Small (0.5-1kb), carry a single gene, often lack a promoter. It can exist as free circular cassette, but only functional when it is inserted into an integron.
Integron: It has intl (a site specific recombinase), recombination site, and a promoter for cassete gene expression. They are not mobile by themselves, but embeded in transposons.
Unit transposons (Tn): Larger than IS, carry additional genes, such as antibiotic resistance genes.
Plasmids: Self replicating extrachromosomal DNA. They often carry multiple MGE including IS, transposon
Serotype: groups bacteria/viruses using antigen or toher molecule on the their surfaces
Convergent evolution: evolution process that is driven by environment adaptation from distantly related species.
Pseudogene: Region that resemble gene structure but inactive due to mutation/IS insertion
Pseudo-Compound Transposons: DNA sequence that is flanked by two IS26s in the same direction, carrying antibiotic resistance genes.
Putative transposase: Predicted to be transposase (using sequence similarity, motifs, etc), but it’s not experimentally confirmed.
Flanking sequence: DNA sequences that adjacent to the IS element, on the left and right ends.

title: Week 01: literature review, exploring relevant databases, and evaluating IS detection tools
text:
Weekly project meeting

Tom introduced eris, and explained how the tool works.
Leah made google docs to list the things that I need to do
Leah and Tom send IS related papers for me to study

Submitted the Bunya application form.
Need to wait 48 hours to get respond from RCC.
Started reading the following papers:

IS-capades of Klebsiella pneumoniae: Insertion sequences drive metabolic loss in obscure sub-lineages


These four sub lineages SL91 and SL10031 (also referred to as subspecies 19 ozaenae), SL10032 (subspecies rhinoscleromatis) and SL82 have relatively high number of IS, each with differenT profile. These high number of IS are linked to the loss of the ability to use many nutrients for metabolic process.
IS may affect metabolism by directly disrupting nearby genes or indirectly through genome rearrangements over time. Despite these loses, the sub lineages still keep a core of metabolic traits that likely help the survive.


A metagenomics pipeline reveals insertion sequence-driven evolution of the microbiota


Developed new IS database ISOSDB, expanding IS diversity of ISfinder, it is built from single and metagenome data.
Built the pseudoR to wok with the new database, can use metagenomic data for the input.
IS in gut bacteria is diverse regardless of the lifestyle and geopgraphy. These inertions usually target accessory genes (not cor genes for survival?)
iORF evenets is usually unique to individual microbiome
IS insertions are temporary stable and maintained, and others only detected at specific timepoint. Microbiota actively forming new insertions.
Antibiotic pressure cause significant loss of IS diversity, and usually unrecovered afftar the expossure.
Diet intervensions affect the IS insertions, in respond to metabolic process adaptation






Started reading the following papers:

Mobile Genetic Elements Associated with Antimicrobial Resistance


Review specieally highlights ESKAPEE pathogens (E. coli, K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, S. aureus) in the resistance dissemination.
MGE including IS, transposon, integron, gene cassette, plasmid are driver horizontal gene transfer of resistance genes among pathogenes. They play significant role in the acquisition, accumulation, and dissemination of antimicrobial resistence (AMR) genes.
Classification of IS by:

Amino acids transpoase motifs, DDE (Asp-Asp-Glu) is the most common.
Transposition mechanisms, cut or copy paste

Terminal inverted repeats typically found at both end of IS
ISfinder is manually curated database for IS elements.
Naming shceme: it comnbines species origin and an ID number (e.g., ISAba1 from Acinetobacter baumannii).
IS can activate resistance genes by inserting upstream, distruping genes nearby, or facilitating cimposite transposon
IS can flank resistence gene(s) to form composite transposon
IS integrate into plasmid, driving HGT
Multiple identical MGE collapse during WGS assembly, resistance islands become fragmented across contigs






My access request to Bunya HPC has been approved.
Logged into HPC, set up keygen ssh
Started reading the following papers:

Everyman’s Guide to Bacterial Insertion Sequences


IS play big roles in the genomic evolutions, including gene rearrangement, gene modulation, and HGT.
THey have high diversity > 4000 identified IS, it will increase along with sequencing project, and make it the boundaries with other MGE less clear
Family definitions are qualitative/descriptive.
IS is defined a short (0.7 and 2.5 kb) DNA elements encoding only enzymes requires for its mobility. Their genetic compotition are compact with mosly two open reading frames (orfs) which occupy the entire length of the IS and terminate in flanking imperfect terminal repeat sequences (IR).
ISfinder is curated IS database as well as it provides a framework for nomenclature and IS classification into related groups or families.
Major IS groups is characterised by the chemestry they use to breaking and rejoining: motif DDE (and DEDD) and HUH enzymes.
DDE transposases IS are distinguished by the second (“nontransferred”) strand is processed:

Coointegrate (copy and paste): IS6
Cut and paste in, with 2 bp footprint in donor site: IS630
Cut and paste in, with haipin formation: IS4
Replicate circle formed, with donor retained (copy and paste): IS3, IS2, IS911

IS is ismple TE with only transpoase, composite transposon is two IS elements flanking genes, unit tranposon is ingle unit Tpase with cargo, ICE is integrated + conjugative transfer
Transporter IS carry passager genes that are not related to mobility, antibiotic resistance genes (ISCgl1, IS481 family)
IS91/ISCR group is associated with diverse antibiotic resistance genes
IS can rapidly invrease copy number (expansion), remove unnecessary genes (in nuitrient rich environtment).
IS can modulate gene expression (resistance gene) in two main ways:

insert in coding sequence and distrupt the expression
bring the promoter, induce gene activation.

IS insertion is not entirely random:

Some IS prefer specific motifs, IS630 prefer TA in the target
Some IS prefer AT-rich or GC-rich regions

ISfinder groups IS into families based on structural and functional characteristics (Transpoase motifs, IR, TSD, orf, target preference, etc)
29 IS families identified in ISfinder
IS doesn’t include every IS that exists, the sequence come from reseachers who studied and submited it. New database expansion or exploration will likely lead to new families or groups.
IS1 (DDE transpoase) plays a role in spreading antibiotic resistence by flanking that genes on transposon or plasmid.
IS3 (DDE transpoase) is the biggest IS family with >550 members found in > 270 species


ISfinder: the reference centre for bacterial insertion sequences


ISfinder defines ISD as short genetically compact DNA segments (between 0.7 and 2.5 kb) encoding no functions other than those involved in their mobility.
ISfinder is manual curation (need to fill out the submission form) exclusively for IS database. It also play role as Inaming convention/nomenclature).
Follow naming system from restriction enzyme. example: ISKpn1 (found in Klebsiella pneumoniae, and unique identifier 1). Drawback: some IS elements are found in multiple taxa. Hystorical number blocks are preserved in the database.
ISfinder utilises MySQL structure
It provides: DNA sequence, orf/poteintal coding sequence, TIR and TSD, Taxonomic origin, IS family, reference, NCBI taxonomy, also tools like BLAST.






Completed the Health Safety and Wellness Induction training on Blackboard
Complerted the Annual Fire Safety training on Blackboard
Started reading the following papers:

Quantitative assessment of insertion sequence impact on bacterial genome architecture


They introduced ISseeker to anotate IS element in the draft genome assembly
Using genome assembly draft as an input, less computational cost.
It identifies IS by blasting their flanking sequences (500 bp) to a reference genome. Both full long contigs includes IS and flanks and and truncated IS (but flanks remain)
These flank can tell us where the IS location in the host genome.
If match is found, IS is annotated as mapped. The location relative to adjacent genes in the reference genome (user specified) is reported.
It doesn’t use ISfinder
It does not give us the full inserted sequence, it doesn’t classifiy IS, it doesn’t give functional effect
Phylogenetically they suggested that many IS insertion in A. baumannii and K. pneumoniae are conserved.
IS elements can insert intragenically (within genes) or intergenically (between genes)
Multiple IS insertion in same region (A. baumannii)
Although the genome size is about 30 % smaller than K. pneumoniae genomes (~5.6 Mbp), IS element density from A. baumannii is greater.


Impact of insertion sequences on convergent evolution of Shigella species


IS in Shigella genomes account 5-8% of bases, much higher than E.coli with <1%.
They used ISMapper to identify insertion sites in chromosomes.
Within each Shigella species (S. dysenteriae, S. flexneri, S. sonnei), there are variation in both the number and the location of IS insertion. These IS insertion patterns could be use to differentiate phylogenetic lineages.

IS26 has unquie moving mechanism, that enables them spreading resistence genes. It has two distinct cointegration, Pseudo composite transposon (PCT) formation.

title: Week 07: Investigating missed calls and overcalls by eris, and attempting to resolve fragmented IS sequences
text:
All IS element that is missed by Eris are truncated (not full) sequences in the complete chromosome. Isescan missed one full IS sequence.
2 (IS609 and ISEc52) of 4 eris missed IS elements have 600-800 bp long, hit to IS sequencen ISfinder with high identity and 0 E value.
MITEEc1, IS1397, IS100kyp, ISKox3, ISEch14, ISEc10, IS21 are likely to be true exist in the EC958 complete chromosome sequence.
Eris (and isescan) overcounted the number of IS in the genome asssembly result, because they counted a fragmented IS sequence separtely.
Fragmented IS also appear when I used mason to simulte the reads.
By graph traversal logic, fragmented IS sequnces (nodes in the graph) can be collapsed and the IS copies can be quantified by their contig depths relative to the median depth
FragGeneScanRs detected more ORFs than Pyrodgial. It is more sensitive than Pyrodgial, but has lower precision score.






Weekly project meeting

Dimas will inspect more IS that eris missed, as well as the extra IS
Workaround to get IS name from isescan is to extract the sequence using genomic coordimnate and blast it to the ISfinder
Need resolve fragmented IS elements that eris (also isescan) detects seperately, for instance:

Using graph logic for traversing the graph until we don’t get the mobile_element (consider the adjacent and also orientation)
block mapping









!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed -v  | bedtools getfasta -name -fi ../../data/ecoli/EC958.fasta -bed - > IS_eris_missed.fasta

ISfinder blast result from those four Eris missed IS elements can be accessed here

HG941718.1 2103782 2104446 : truncated at both ends IS609 (origin: Escherichia coli, length: 664 bp) is real, hit on the BLAST with E value 0.0. True IS609.
HG941718.1 3312816 3313143 truncated by IS30 has two equal E value and score bits on BLAST ISSfl10 and IS600. It has 327 of 1237 total element length. Too short? is this still functional?
HG941718.1 4922924 4923251 truncated at right end of IS hits to ISLad1 (327 of 1249 bp length), score = 430 bits
HG941718.1 4943650 4944441 truncated at left end by IS600 95% is real, identified as ISEc52 (791 of 1250 bp) on ISfinder, E value 0.

Two of them have E value 0 on BLAST, all truncated.




!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/EC958.fasta.bed -v  | bedtools getfasta -name -fi ../../data/ecoli/EC958.fasta -bed - > IS_isescan_missed.fasta

ISfinder blast result can be accessed here
It has different missed IS calls with eris

HG941718.1 1365600 1366443 hits to ISCfr4 (843 of 1253 bp), Evalue 0
HG941718.1 3312816 3313143 truncated by IS30 hits to ISSfl10 (327 of 1237 bp)
HG941718.1 3313143 3314364 insertion sequence:IS30 hits to IS30 and IS30D (1221 of 1221 bp), Evalue 0

my approach is like this:

Organise all the identified IS

collect all identified IS elements with their corresponding contigs in the genome

Genome assembly graph reconstruction

Build the directed graph representation of the genome assembly
For each identified IS:

Boundary identification


Locate the boundaries of fragmented IS sequence within the graph, determine the start and and nodes.
I use outdegree edges and indegree edges to find it

end node = no outgoing edges to the nodes of the same IS, at leat two levels
start node = no ingoing edges from nodes that has same IS, at least two levels

but the problem is, some nodes have no indegree at all and others have no outdegree..


Graph traversal and copy quantification


From the identified start node, find the shortest path to the corresponding end node. It may pass through contigs that are not marked as the same IS
While traversing, estimate the number of IS copies in the genome by comparing the node depth to global median depth of all nodes in the genome
In the traversing graph, quantify the IS copies by the depth of the node

For example, id the median depth is 30x, and it finds a node that has 92x depth in the traversing process, it estimate the IS has 3 copies. It rounds to the nearest integer.


Note: It may struggle to traverse in the nodes that have complicated outgoing and ingoing edges. It hasn’t include stard orientation when traversing. Also, this approach maybe not very efficient. But let’s try using two simulated read dataset: art_modern and mason that is going to shovill assembly. Use the gfa from it as an input.

title: Week 07: Investigating missed calls and overcalls by eris, and attempting to resolve fragmented IS sequences
text:
Weekly project meeting

Dimas will inspect more IS that eris missed, as well as the extra IS
Workaround to get IS name from isescan is to extract the sequence using genomic coordimnate and blast it to the ISfinder
Need resolve fragmented IS elements that eris (also isescan) detects seperately, for instance:

Using graph logic for traversing the graph until we don’t get the mobile_element (consider the adjacent and also orientation)
block mapping









!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed -v  | bedtools getfasta -name -fi ../../data/ecoli/EC958.fasta -bed - > IS_eris_missed.fasta

ISfinder blast result from those four Eris missed IS elements can be accessed here

HG941718.1 2103782 2104446 : truncated at both ends IS609 (origin: Escherichia coli, length: 664 bp) is real, hit on the BLAST with E value 0.0. True IS609.
HG941718.1 3312816 3313143 truncated by IS30 has two equal E value and score bits on BLAST ISSfl10 and IS600. It has 327 of 1237 total element length. Too short? is this still functional?
HG941718.1 4922924 4923251 truncated at right end of IS hits to ISLad1 (327 of 1249 bp length), score = 430 bits
HG941718.1 4943650 4944441 truncated at left end by IS600 95% is real, identified as ISEc52 (791 of 1250 bp) on ISfinder, E value 0.

Two of them have E value 0 on BLAST, all truncated.




!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/EC958.fasta.bed -v  | bedtools getfasta -name -fi ../../data/ecoli/EC958.fasta -bed - > IS_isescan_missed.fasta

my approach is like this:

Organise all the identified IS

collect all identified IS elements with their corresponding contigs in the genome

Genome assembly graph reconstruction

Build the directed graph representation of the genome assembly
For each identified IS:

Boundary identification


Locate the boundaries of fragmented IS sequence within the graph, determine the start and and nodes.
I use outdegree edges and indegree edges to find it

end node = no outgoing edges to the nodes of the same IS, at leat two levels
start node = no ingoing edges from nodes that has same IS, at least two levels

but the problem is, some nodes have no indegree at all and others have no outdegree..


Graph traversal and copy quantification


From the identified start node, find the shortest path to the corresponding end node. It may pass through contigs that are not marked as the same IS
While traversing, estimate the number of IS copies in the genome by comparing the node depth to global median depth of all nodes in the genome
In the traversing graph, quantify the IS copies by the depth of the node

For example, id the median depth is 30x, and it finds a node that has 92x depth in the traversing process, it estimate the IS has 3 copies. It rounds to the nearest integer.


Note: It may struggle to traverse in the nodes that have complicated outgoing and ingoing edges. It hasn’t include stard orientation when traversing. Also, this approach maybe not very efficient. But let’s try using two simulated read dataset: art_modern and mason that is going to shovill assembly. Use the gfa from it as an input.

title: Computational Lab Logbook
text:
This document records all computational work for the project: De novo identification of insertion sequences with De Bruijn graphs.
Insertion sequences (IS) are small DNA elements that can replicate and move throughout a bacterial genome independently. This ability often results in their insertion upstream of or within genes, which consequently leads to large effects on gene expression within the bacteria. These changes in expression can affect a multitude of phenotypes, including resistance to antibiotics and virulence. As such, is it necessary that we characterise where these IS move to within the genome.
Unfortunately, as IS are small and repetitive throughout the genome, they cause issues for short-read de novo assemblers, most notably collapsed repeats. Because of this, it can be difficult to determine the exact location of IS throughout the genome.
The goal is to build an end-to-end pipeline that: - Detect de novo IS using de Brujin graphs - Quantify a collection of bacterial genomes for the effect of IS sequences on the phenotype.

title: Computational Lab Logbook
text:
This document records all computational work for the project: De novo identification of insertion sequences with De Bruijn graphs.
Insertion sequences (IS) are small DNA elements that can replicate and move throughout a bacterial genome independently. This ability often results in their insertion upstream of or within genes, which consequently leads to large effects on gene expression within the bacteria. These changes in expression can affect a multitude of phenotypes, including resistance to antibiotics and virulence. As such, is it necessary that we characterise where these IS move to within the genome.
Unfortunately, as IS are small and repetitive throughout the genome, they cause issues for short-read de novo assemblers, most notably collapsed repeats. Because of this, it can be difficult to determine the exact location of IS throughout the genome.
The goal is to build an end-to-end pipeline that: - Detect de novo IS using de Brujin graphs - Quantify a collection of bacterial genomes for the effect of IS sequences on the phenotype.

title: Computational Lab Logbook
text:
Glossary

Insertion Sequence (IS): Short DNA sequence that can replicate and move within genome. Their activity can modulate gene expression and cause genomic rearrangements
De Brujin–graph: A graph representation of overlapping sequence. Nodes represent (k-1)-mers and edges represent k-mers. An edge connects two nodes if the suffix of the first (k-1)-mer overlaps with the prefix of the second (k-1)-mer.

title: Week 09: Reannotate IS from EC958, Run PseudoR, and annotated other assemblies data using isescan
text:
Weekly project meeting

Dimas will reannoate IS from EC958. Adding newly detected IS that are confrimed as true IS. Also, if there are two same IS copies, adding suffix _1, _2, etc.
Run pseudoR on EC958 genome, and parse the result in a way that can have ISfinder nomenclature
Run isescan on the bacterial genome from Hall et all paper, and later run eris. Identify if any additional IS called by eris compared to isescan, and if any IS missed by eris relative to isescan result.
Use isescan results as the “truthset”
Compare IS effect prediction (such as upregulated and downregulated) between complete sequence and draft assembly






Dimas has rewritten IS annotation of EC958, in a total of 49 IS elements identified in the chromosome sequence. For IS name with multiple copies, each copy is labeled with a suffix _1, _2, _3, and so on.





I ran pseudoR with simulated EC958 reads using the complete EC958 chromosome as the reference. I also tried using simulated reads with the assembly contigs, and real reads with the complete chromosome. All these runs failed during the post-processing step when making the output. This is similar to issue #6. In these runs, some some trimmed reads are mapped to IS elements, but they were all filtered out in post-processing, so no entries were left, and the program gave an error. In other words, I suspect that there were no strong IS insertions detected by pseudoR in these cases.
I aso tried to change the database to ISfinder sequence, but had no luck as well
But when I used real read data with the assembly made from it and used ISOSDB, the run was successful. It detected several IS from ISOSDB in the data


!source pseudoR_single-reference.sh sraList=my-list.txt threads=10 database=/scratch/user/s4897040/pseudoR \
  dedupe=../data/ecoli958/fastqs/ mode=s reference=../outputs/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta \
  read1_ending=_1.fastq.gz read2_ending=_2.fastq.gz IR_database=/scratch/user/s4897040/pseudoR


I tried to compare IS from ISOSDB that were detected by pseudoR with ISFinder. Since the authors mentioned that they use homology with ISFinder sequences (not exact matches) as one of their criteria when they building the ISOSDB, I also searched them using BLAST.


# build ISfinder database (for blast)
!makeblastdb -dbtype nucl -in IS.fna


# extract only the IS name field from the report
!tail +2  ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/pseudoR_output.contig.tsv | cut -f 2 > ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/list_isosdb_names.txt

# pull out the sequences from ISOSDB by IS name or header
!seqkit grep -n -f ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/list_isosdb_names.txt ../../ISOSDB.V3.fna -o ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/SRR5194982_pseudoR_ISOSDB.fna

# blast ISOSDB sequence query to ISfinder, select only the max hit per query sequence
!blastn -query ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/SRR5194982_pseudoR_ISOSDB.fna -db ../../eris/src/eris/data/IS.fna -outfmt 6 -evalue 1e-3 -max_target_seqs 1 -out SRR5194982_blast_ISOSDB_ISfinder.txt


import pandas as pd

isosdb = pd.read_csv("../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/pseudoR_output.contig.tsv", sep="\t")

isosdb_blast = pd.read_csv("../SRR5194982_blast_ISOSDB_ISfinder.tsv",
sep="\t", header=None,
names=["IS", "ISfinder name", "identity", "alignment length", "mismatches", "gap opens", "q. start", "q. end", "s. start", "s. end", "evalue", "bit score"])

# Keep only the first occurrence of each IS, get the highest hit and lowest e value
isosdb_blast_uniq = isosdb_blast.drop_duplicates(subset=["IS"], keep="first")

# left join
isosdb_isfinder = pd.merge(isosdb, isosdb_blast_uniq, on="IS", how="left")
isosdb_isfinder[["IS", "ISfinder name", "contig", "Insertion_Position", "identity"]]

eris did not detect any IS elements in the NODE_3 contig. Those IS detected by pseudoR probably don’t exist in the ISfinder database and missed during assembly
After reread the pipeline method described by the author on the paper and his clarification regarding undetected IS here, it appears that pseudoR is primarily intended to detect the movement of IS elements, such as novel insertions, excisions, or differences in insertion sites between samples and a reference, rather than to simply identify the presence of IS elements in a genome.





Run isescan on asssemblies data from Hall et al.


ssubmit -m 64g -t 1d isescan-more "ls ../data/more-bacteria/assemblies/ncbi_dataset/data/*/*.fna | parallel -j 4 isescan.py --seqfile {} --output isescan --nthread 2" -- -c 12


Also, because the outputs from isescan doesnt give us the IS name, I need to extrarct the sequences detected as IS elements and map them into ISfinder, using blast?


# get the fasta generated by isescan to have sequence identifiers by their IS cluster
!awk '/^>/{print ">" $2; next} {print}' ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/chromosome/EC958.fasta.is.fna > ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/chromosome/EC958.fasta.is.cluster.fna

# blast isescan IS query to ISfinder, select only the max hit per query sequence
!blastn -query ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/chromosome/EC958.fasta.is.cluster.fna -db ../../eris/src/eris/data/IS.fna -outfmt 6 -evalue 1e-3 -max_target_seqs 1 -out EC958_blast_isescan_ISfinder.txt


import pandas as pd

isescan = pd.read_csv("../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/chromosome/EC958.fasta.tsv", sep="\t")

isescan_blast = pd.read_csv("EC958_blast_isescan_ISfinder.txt",
sep="\t", header=None,
names=["cluster", "ISfinder name", "identity", "alignment length", "mismatches", "gap opens", "q. start", "q. end", "s. start", "s. end", "evalue", "bit score"])

# Keep only the first occurrence of each IS, get the highest hit and lowest e value
isescan_blast_uniq = isescan_blast.drop_duplicates(subset=["cluster"], keep="first")

# left join
isescan_isfinder = pd.merge(isescan, isescan_blast_uniq, on="cluster", how="left")
print(isescan_isfinder[["cluster", "family", "ISfinder name", "isBegin", "isEnd"]].to_string())

title: Week 09: Reannotate IS from EC958, Run PseudoR, and annotated other assemblies data using isescan
text:
Weekly project meeting

Dimas will reannoate IS from EC958. Adding newly detected IS that are confrimed as true IS. Also, if there are two same IS copies, adding suffix _1, _2, etc.
Run pseudoR on EC958 genome, and parse the result in a way that can have ISfinder nomenclature
Run isescan on the bacterial genome from Hall et all paper, and later run eris. Identify if any additional IS called by eris compared to isescan, and if any IS missed by eris relative to isescan result.
Use isescan results as the “truthset”
Compare IS effect prediction (such as upregulated and downregulated) between complete sequence and draft assembly






Dimas has rewritten IS annotation of EC958, in a total of 49 IS elements identified in the chromosome sequence. For IS name with multiple copies, each copy is labeled with a suffix _1, _2, _3, and so on.





I ran pseudoR with simulated EC958 reads using the complete EC958 chromosome as the reference. I also tried using simulated reads with the assembly contigs, and real reads with the complete chromosome. All these runs failed during the post-processing step when making the output. This is similar to issue #6. In these runs, some some trimmed reads are mapped to IS elements, but they were all filtered out in post-processing, so no entries were left, and the program gave an error. In other words, I suspect that there were no strong IS insertions detected by pseudoR in these cases.
I aso tried to change the database to ISfinder sequence, but had no luck as well
But when I used real read data with the assembly made from it and used ISOSDB, the run was successful. It detected several IS from ISOSDB in the data


!source pseudoR_single-reference.sh sraList=my-list.txt threads=10 database=/scratch/user/s4897040/pseudoR \
  dedupe=../data/ecoli958/fastqs/ mode=s reference=../outputs/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta \
  read1_ending=_1.fastq.gz read2_ending=_2.fastq.gz IR_database=/scratch/user/s4897040/pseudoR


I tried to compare IS from ISOSDB that were detected by pseudoR with ISFinder. Since the authors mentioned that they use homology with ISFinder sequences (not exact matches) as one of their criteria when they building the ISOSDB, I also searched them using BLAST.


# build ISfinder database (for blast)
!makeblastdb -dbtype nucl -in IS.fna


# extract only the IS name field from the report
!tail +2  ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/pseudoR_output.contig.tsv | cut -f 2 > ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/list_isosdb_names.txt

# pull out the sequences from ISOSDB by IS name or header
!seqkit grep -n -f ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/list_isosdb_names.txt ../../ISOSDB.V3.fna -o ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/SRR5194982_pseudoR_ISOSDB.fna

# blast ISOSDB sequence query to ISfinder, select only the max hit per query sequence
!blastn -query ../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/SRR5194982_pseudoR_ISOSDB.fna -db ../../eris/src/eris/data/IS.fna -outfmt 6 -evalue 1e-3 -max_target_seqs 1 -out SRR5194982_blast_ISOSDB_ISfinder.txt


import pandas as pd

isosdb = pd.read_csv("../../data/ecoli/pseudoR-outputs/pseudoR_output.contig.tsv", sep="\t")

isosdb_blast = pd.read_csv("../SRR5194982_blast_ISOSDB_ISfinder.tsv",
sep="\t", header=None,
names=["IS", "ISfinder name", "identity", "alignment length", "mismatches", "gap opens", "q. start", "q. end", "s. start", "s. end", "evalue", "bit score"])

# Keep only the first occurrence of each IS, get the highest hit and lowest e value
isosdb_blast_uniq = isosdb_blast.drop_duplicates(subset=["IS"], keep="first")

# left join
isosdb_isfinder = pd.merge(isosdb, isosdb_blast_uniq, on="IS", how="left")
isosdb_isfinder[["IS", "ISfinder name", "contig", "Insertion_Position", "identity"]]

title: Week 09: Reannotate IS from EC958, Run PseudoR, and annotated other assemblies data using isescan
text:
What approach, in a reproducible way, we can use to compare Element_effect (and Effect_location) prediction from bertween full chromosome sequence and draft assembly/contigs? - because we can’t rely on the genomic coordinates, can we focus on the number? such as: - Count how many Element_location and Element_Effect type between two sources - We can group the IS and count what is the Element_location and Element_effect
::: {#e86d80eb .cell execution_count=9} {.python .cell-code}   {"IS256": {       "intragenic": {"disrupted": 2, "upregulated": 1},       "upstream":   {"disrupted": 1}       }   }
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} {'IS256': {'intragenic': {'disrupted': 2, 'upregulated': 1},     'upstream': {'disrupted': 1}}} ::: :::
And compare is this representative enough to compare each insertion effect between the two sources?

Can we have gene annotation from each gene? and compare the whether the effect is identical for each gene between two sources?

::: {#92deaaa8 .cell execution_count=10} {.python .cell-code}   ("gene", "IS_name", "Element_location", "Element_effect")
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ('gene', 'IS_name', 'Element_location', 'Element_effect') ::: :::

title: Week 08: Playing around with minimap2 settings and downloaded bacterial genomes
text:
Weekly project meeting
All the IS that eris missed are truncated sequences. I will extract the sequences from the chromosome and play around with minimap2 settings in eris to understand why they were missed. Try to change the preset setting, maybe it is more appropiate
For fragmented IS spread across multiple contigs, I wrote a module using a graph traversal approach to collapse them and quantify their copy numbers. It works quite well on some identified IS and can correct both undercounted and overcounted IS from contigs.
FragGeneScan has better sensitivity, but lower precision compared to pyrodigal on EC958. It is because FragGeneScan can predict on the truncated ORF sequence?
Use F1 score to include the balance of senisitivity and precision.
Dimas will read through Michael’s paper and download the dataset





Tried different preset on minimap2 when aligning IS sequences against the input complete chromosome sequence

preset minimap2 default, lr:hq, and asm5 still don’t find IS that missed by eris on the complete EC958 sequence. Using sr ( Short-read alignment without splicing), minimap can detect the missed IS


# convert paf file to bed, for easy checking
!awk -v OFS="\t" '{print $6, $8, $9, $1, $11/$2}' ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/sr_chromosome_minimap2.paf | bedtools sort -i - > ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/sr_chromosome_minimap2.bed

# intersect missed IS with sr minimap2 bed file
!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed -v | bedtools intersect -a - -b ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/sr_chromosome_minimap2.bed -wb

HG941718.1  2104183 2104431 truncated at both ends 95% identical to IS609 from  0   +   HG941718.1  2104183 2104431 IS609_IS200/IS605_IS605/1   0.141876
HG941718.1  2104183 2104431 truncated at both ends 95% identical to IS609 from  0   +   HG941718.1  2104183 2104431 IS609_IS200/IS605_IS605/2   0.141876
HG941718.1  4943805 4943830 truncated at left end by IS600 95% identical to 0   +   HG941718.1  4943805 4943830 ISBrsa1_IS3_IS3 0.020016



Using preset rs, it detects 2 of 4 missed IS, but with poor quality. It detected IS609 in position G941718.1:2104183-2104431 that eris missed, but the coverage is very low (14%) of 664bp query length. Also, detected IS in position HG941718.1:4943805-4943830, but mistakenly identified as ISBrsa1 with very low coverage of (2%), when ISfinder hit on ISEc52
And how many overcalls? intersect minimap2 result with “truth” IS coordinates, count how many etries from minimap2 have no overlap:

!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/sr_chromosome_minimap2.bed -b ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -v | wc -l

      52


More sensitive, but more prone to positive false.

Eris map a list of IS nucleotide sequences against query sequence (can be contigs or, in this case, complete chromosome). However, if we treat the other way around. We map the complete sequence against the IS element sequences (as a reference). All four missed IS are identified by minimap2 (using default preset).. 🤔


# convert paf file to bed, for easy checking
!awk -v OFS="\t" '{print $1, $3, $4, $6, $11/$7}' ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/reversed_chromosome_minimap2.paf | bedtools sort -i - > ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/reversed_chromosome_minimap2.bed

# intersect missed IS with reversed minimap2 bed file
!bedtools intersect -a ../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed -b eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed -v | bedtools intersect -a - -b ../../data/ecoli/minimap2-preset/reversed_chromosome_minimap2.bed -wb

HG941718.1  2103782 2104432 truncated at both ends 95% identical to IS609 from  0   +   HG941718.1  2103782 2104432 IS609_IS200/IS605_IS605 0.371854
HG941718.1  3312822 3313143 truncated by IS30   0   +   HG941718.1  3312822 3315298 ISSd1_IS3_IS3   1.95735
HG941718.1  4922975 4923150 truncated at right end of IS    0   +   HG941718.1  4922975 4923150 ISLad1_IS3_IS3  0.140112
HG941718.1  4943671 4944385 truncated at left end by IS600 95% identical to 0   +   HG941718.1  4943671 4944385 ISEc52_IS3_IS3  0.572



By manually inspection, all copies of two missed IS that we decided as true IS elements, IS609 and ISEc52 actually were corercty detected from input draft assembly.
IS609 has two copies in EC958 where at HG941718.1:2103782-2104446 and HG941718.1:3820313-3821771. The later that eris missed from input chromosome. From draft assembly (contigs), eris originally detected as 3 copies (see week 06), but after we collapse the graphs, it has indeed 2 copies ( see week 07).
ISEc52 has three copies at HG941718.1:3558365-3559615, HG941718.1 5007344 5008594, and missed HG941718.1:4943671-4944385. When we give eris draft assembly as an input, 5 cointigs detected to have ISEc52, and after the contigs is collapsed, it only has 2 copies (issue with nodes that have no indegree or no outdegree)
question, can i rewrite IS annotations of EC958 so that each entry has single IS name?





Downloaded assembly and annotation files and Illumina reads data from Hall M et al.

title: Week 06: Scan IS elements both from complete chromosome and simulated read contigs
text:
Weekly project meeting

Dimas has submitted the project plan on the Blackboard
Dimas started to work on the truth dataset E coli 958

There are 41 IS annotated in the chromosome + 1 mistery IS
There are 12 IS annotated in the plasmid pEC958
RTotal 53 + 1 mistery IS

Dimas will try simulate reads from the chromosome only, this will help:

Get only reads from chromosome, not from plasmid
Handle noise from different genetic composition in the isolates
Also test the the assembly again

Using bedtools to find the intersection region IS detected by Eris and other tools with truth










!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/EC958.fasta > eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.tsv


!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.tsv | wc -l

      58


Eris identified 58 IS in full genome

import pandas as pd
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)
eris_chr = pd.read_csv("eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.tsv", sep="\t")
eris_chr = eris_chr[eris_chr['Type'] == "mobile_element"]


# convert the mobile element entries into bed file
eris_chr["Score"] = "0"
eris_chr = eris_chr.assign(
    StrandBed = eris_chr["Strand"].apply(lambda x: "+" if x == 1 else "-")
)
eris_chr_bed = eris_chr[["Contig", "Start", "End", "Name", "Score", "StrandBed", "Percent_coverage"]]
eris_chr_bed.to_csv("eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed", sep="\t", index=False, header=False)

Started to simulate Illumina reads from the chromosme sequence only using art_modern

#| eval: false
~/bin/art_modern/opt/build_release/art_modern --mode wgs --lc pe --i-file ../fastas/EC958.fasta --o-fastq ./EC958_pe --qual_file_1 ~/bin/art_modern/data/Illumina_profiles/HiSeq2500L150R1.txt --qual_file_2 ~/bin/art_modern/data/Illumina_profiles/HiSeq2500L150R2.txt --read_len 150 --parallel 2  --i-fcov 150 --pe_frag_dist_mean 400 --pe_frag_dist_std_dev 50
It generated interleaved files are when the R1 and R2 reads are combined in one file. And It seems we R1 identifier on the seq ID with art_modern:1:nompi and art_modern:2:nompi for R2. Then, i used seqkit to split the reads into two files.
#| eval: false
seqkit grep -r -p "art_modern:1:nompi" EC958_pe -o EC958.read1.fq.gz
seqkit grep -r -p "art_modern:2:nompi" EC958_pe -o EC958.read1.fq.gz

gzip EC958.read1.fq
gzip EC958.read2.fq



shovill --outdir shovill-outputs/ --R1 ../data/ecoli958/fastqs-art-simulated/EC958.read1.fq.gz --R2 ../data/ecoli958/fastqs-art-simulated/EC958.read2.fq.gz



#| eval: false
eris scan ../shovill-outputs/contigs.fa > eris-outputs/eris_fasta_shovill_sim.tsv
eris scan ../shovill-outputs/contigs.gfa > eris-outputs /eris_gfa_shovill_sim.tsv

!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/eris_fasta_shovill_sim.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/eris_gfa_shovill_sim.tsv | wc -l

title: Week 06: Scan IS elements both from complete chromosome and simulated read contigs
text:
Weekly project meeting

Dimas has submitted the project plan on the Blackboard
Dimas started to work on the truth dataset E coli 958

There are 41 IS annotated in the chromosome + 1 mistery IS
There are 12 IS annotated in the plasmid pEC958
RTotal 53 + 1 mistery IS

Dimas will try simulate reads from the chromosome only, this will help:

Get only reads from chromosome, not from plasmid
Handle noise from different genetic composition in the isolates
Also test the the assembly again

Using bedtools to find the intersection region IS detected by Eris and other tools with truth

import pandas as pd
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)
eris_chr = pd.read_csv("eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.tsv", sep="\t")
eris_chr = eris_chr[eris_chr['Type'] == "mobile_element"]


# convert the mobile element entries into bed file
eris_chr["Score"] = "0"
eris_chr = eris_chr.assign(
    StrandBed = eris_chr["Strand"].apply(lambda x: "+" if x == 1 else "-")
)
eris_chr_bed = eris_chr[["Contig", "Start", "End", "Name", "Score", "StrandBed", "Percent_coverage"]]
eris_chr_bed.to_csv("eris-outputs/chromosome_fasta.bed", sep="\t", index=False, header=False)

Started to simulate Illumina reads from the chromosme sequence only using art_modern

#| eval: false
~/bin/art_modern/opt/build_release/art_modern --mode wgs --lc pe --i-file ../fastas/EC958.fasta --o-fastq ./EC958_pe --qual_file_1 ~/bin/art_modern/data/Illumina_profiles/HiSeq2500L150R1.txt --qual_file_2 ~/bin/art_modern/data/Illumina_profiles/HiSeq2500L150R2.txt --read_len 150 --parallel 2  --i-fcov 150 --pe_frag_dist_mean 400 --pe_frag_dist_std_dev 50
It generated interleaved files are when the R1 and R2 reads are combined in one file. And It seems we R1 identifier on the seq ID with art_modern:1:nompi and art_modern:2:nompi for R2. Then, i used seqkit to split the reads into two files.
#| eval: false
seqkit grep -r -p "art_modern:1:nompi" EC958_pe -o EC958.read1.fq.gz
seqkit grep -r -p "art_modern:2:nompi" EC958_pe -o EC958.read1.fq.gz

gzip EC958.read1.fq
gzip EC958.read2.fq

title: Week 05: Joined Bunya training and started exploring the test dataset E coli 958
text:
Weekly project meeting

Leah and Tom have given comments on the project plan draft
Dimas has already address some of tthe comments
Add typical IS figure
Add figure on how IS can mess up the de brujin graph
Add PseudoR in the benchmarking tool againts






Finalised the project plan, and submitted to the BlackBoard
Joined the Bunya HPC training

There are three drives: home (just for login), scratch (fast access, temporary for 90 days), and RDM (back up here, slow access, for storing)
Do any cimputattion activity in the compute node
onBunya intro, interactive way to get acces to the Bunya from web browser






Started to explore the testing dataset E coli 958

Downloaded the genbank file, and visualise it on the artemis
Downloaded the illumina paired end reads, from ENA SRR5194982


wget -nc ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR519/002/SRR5194982/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz
wget -nc ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR519/002/SRR5194982/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz

Assemblied the Illumina reads using spades


~/bin/SPAdes-4.2.0-Linux/bin/spades.py -1 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz -2 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz --threads 8 --memory 32 -o outputs/spades/


Assemblied the Illumina reads using spades (with --isolate)


~/bin/SPAdes-4.2.0-Linux/bin/spades.py --isolate -1 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz -2 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz --threads 8 --memory 32 -o outputs/spades-isolates






!mkdir -p eris-outputs
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-isolates/assembly_graph_after_simplification.gfa > eris-outputs/result_gfa_isolate.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta > eris-outputs/result_fasta_isolate.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-outputs/assembly_graph_after_simplification.gfa > eris-outputs/result_gfa.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-outputs/contigs.fasta > eris-outputs/result_fasta.tsv

how many IS detected by Eris?

!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_gfa_isolate.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_fasta_isolate.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_gfa.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_fasta.tsv | wc -l

     139
      66
      89
      61


Eris results seems to be influenced by what input file type (gfa or fasta) and how assembly genome is genereated (with or without –isolate flag).




!isescan.py --seqfile outputs/spades-isolate/contigs.fasta --output outputs/isescan/ --nthread 2
!isescan.py --seqfile outputs/spades/contigs.fasta --output outputs/isescan/ --nthread 2

how many IS detected by Isescan?

!tail +2 ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/spades/contigs.fasta.tsv | wc -l
!tail +2 ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta.tsv | wc -l

      58
      77

IS identifier with mobile_element and genomic coordinate in one line, and line after it, follows the IS name.. sometimes with unclassified and no IS family

# get IS features only from the genbank file, and convert it into bed file
import re, os

os.remove("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed")
pattern = r"(\d+)\.\.(\d+)"

with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958.gb", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    for i, line in enumerate(lines):
        if "LOCUS" in line:
            chromosome = line.split()[1] + ".1"
        if "mobile_element" in line.split():
            region = re.search(pattern, line)
            start, end = region.group().split("..")
            orientation = "-" if "complement" in line else "+"
            name = lines[i+1].split("=")[1]
            name = name.replace('"', '').replace(";", "").strip()
            with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed", "a") as output:
                output.write(f"{chromosome}\t{int(start)-1}\t{end}\t{name}\t{0}\t{orientation}\n")


pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)
genome_is_bed = pd.read_csv("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed", sep="\t", header=None)

genome_is_bed.columns = ["chrom", "start", "end", "name", "score", "strand"][:genome_is_bed.shape[1]]

title: Week 05: Joined Bunya training and started exploring the test dataset E coli 958
text:
Weekly project meeting

Leah and Tom have given comments on the project plan draft
Dimas has already address some of tthe comments
Add typical IS figure
Add figure on how IS can mess up the de brujin graph
Add PseudoR in the benchmarking tool againts






Finalised the project plan, and submitted to the BlackBoard
Joined the Bunya HPC training

There are three drives: home (just for login), scratch (fast access, temporary for 90 days), and RDM (back up here, slow access, for storing)
Do any cimputattion activity in the compute node
onBunya intro, interactive way to get acces to the Bunya from web browser






Started to explore the testing dataset E coli 958

Downloaded the genbank file, and visualise it on the artemis
Downloaded the illumina paired end reads, from ENA SRR5194982


wget -nc ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR519/002/SRR5194982/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz
wget -nc ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR519/002/SRR5194982/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz

Assemblied the Illumina reads using spades


~/bin/SPAdes-4.2.0-Linux/bin/spades.py -1 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz -2 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz --threads 8 --memory 32 -o outputs/spades/


Assemblied the Illumina reads using spades (with --isolate)


~/bin/SPAdes-4.2.0-Linux/bin/spades.py --isolate -1 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_1.fastq.gz -2 data/ecoli958/fastqs/SRR5194982_2.fastq.gz --threads 8 --memory 32 -o outputs/spades-isolates






!mkdir -p eris-outputs
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-isolates/assembly_graph_after_simplification.gfa > eris-outputs/result_gfa_isolate.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta > eris-outputs/result_fasta_isolate.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-outputs/assembly_graph_after_simplification.gfa > eris-outputs/result_gfa.tsv
!eris scan ../../data/ecoli/spades-outputs/contigs.fasta > eris-outputs/result_fasta.tsv

how many IS detected by Eris?

!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_gfa_isolate.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_fasta_isolate.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_gfa.tsv | wc -l
!grep "mobile_element" eris-outputs/result_fasta.tsv | wc -l

     139
      66
      89
      61


Eris results seems to be influenced by what input file type (gfa or fasta) and how assembly genome is genereated (with or without –isolate flag).




!isescan.py --seqfile outputs/spades-isolate/contigs.fasta --output outputs/isescan/ --nthread 2
!isescan.py --seqfile outputs/spades/contigs.fasta --output outputs/isescan/ --nthread 2

how many IS detected by Isescan?

!tail +2 ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/spades/contigs.fasta.tsv | wc -l
!tail +2 ../../data/ecoli/isescan-outputs/spades-isolates/contigs.fasta.tsv | wc -l

      58
      77

# get IS features only from the genbank file, and convert it into bed file
import re, os

os.remove("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed")
pattern = r"(\d+)\.\.(\d+)"

with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958.gb", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    for i, line in enumerate(lines):
        if "LOCUS" in line:
            chromosome = line.split()[1] + ".1"
        if "mobile_element" in line.split():
            region = re.search(pattern, line)
            start, end = region.group().split("..")
            orientation = "-" if "complement" in line else "+"
            name = lines[i+1].split("=")[1]
            name = name.replace('"', '').replace(";", "").strip()
            with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed", "a") as output:
                output.write(f"{chromosome}\t{int(start)-1}\t{end}\t{name}\t{0}\t{orientation}\n")

with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958.gb", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    for i, line in enumerate(lines):
        if "LOCUS" in line:
            chromosome = line.split()[1]
        if "mobile_element" in line.split():
            region = re.search(pattern, line)
            start, end = region.group().split("..")
            orientation = "+" if "complement" in line else "-"
            name = lines[i+1].split("=")[1]
            with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed", "a") as output:
                output.write(f"{chromosome}\t{int(start)-1}\t{end}\t{name}\t{0}\t{orientation}\n")

# get IS from the genbank file, and convert it into bed file
import re, os

os.remove("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed")
pattern = r"(\d+)\.\.(\d+)"

with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958.gb", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    for i, line in enumerate(lines):
        if "LOCUS" in line:
            chromosome = line.split()[1]
        if "mobile_element" in line.split():
            region = re.search(pattern, line)
            start, end = region.group().split("..")
            orientation = "-" if "complement" in line else "+"
            name = lines[i+1].split("=")[1]
            name = name.replace('"', '').replace(";", "").strip()
            with open("../../data/ecoli/ec958_IS.bed", "a") as output:
                output.write(f"{chromosome}\t{int(start)-1}\t{end}\t{name}\t{0}\t{orientation}\n")

title: Week 03: Started drafting the project plan
text:
Weekly project meeting

Put all the commands Dimas has run to the logbook, will be helpful later
Visualise the result to bandage later
Walked through the code that I explored with Tom adding some insight on Features, Id generations, graph weight
How much is the cut off value form predicting IS insertion and also the effect? hits cutoff and min proximity.
Promoter sequence bacteria is usually can be searched using regular expression with the balence of modularity of the tool and also it has good accuracy
Discuss about the discrepancies of the result between tools (will be disscused more later)
Ask clarification on the project plan assesment
